body:
Looking at this... 1 and 2 can be done in one backward compatible change; older versions will understand this message, newer versions will just see the fields blank when getting it from an older one.

``` diff
@@ -140,6 +140,8 @@ type RequestMessage struct {
        Name    string // max:8192
        Offset  uint64
        Size    uint32
+       Hash    []byte   // max:64
+       Options []Option // max:64
 }
```

Number 3 is tricky, because it's in the middle of a larger message. Breaks compatibility. For number 4, this is fine;

``` diff
 type IndexMessage struct {
        Folder  string // max:64
        Files   []FileInfo
+       Options []Option // max:64
 }
```

For number 6 we could simply

``` diff
 type ResponseMessage struct {
        Data         []byte
+       ErrorCode    uint32
+       ErrorMessage string // max:1024
 }
```

So 3 and 5 are the trickier ones. And also, should we be adding free text "options" fields everywhere, or try to figure out the specifics of what might be needed?
@GeorgeMac, @aral, if you guys have some thoughts here for things you're missing, feel free to jump in.
(Oh and as was said on IRC but not documented, I think sending URL:s as above for discovery is a swell idea)

Note that adding encrypted storage support might well be big enough that it warrants a 2.0 release or a completely separate protocol just for that purpose, so we don't necessarily need to shoehorn that into 1.0.

Oh and the main reason I'm pushing for a soon-ish 1.0 release is that we already have a bunch of users using this in production, and we are seriously considering compatibility issues when developing. That screams of being in 1.0 already in disguise. The standard open source "it's 1.0 when it's done" doesn't really give confidence or make the version number meaningful I think.

+1 for making it 1.0. I think it's stable enough (and yes, I'm one of those using it in production).
From a technical standpoint I would also advocate against adding option fields everywhere "just in case we need them". I'd rather have a concise protocol that changes every few versions than a bloated protocol just for stability's sake.

Given we are going for this v1.0 thing, can we just make the breaking changes I am suggesting for v1.0?
The reason for optional fields is the protocol lockdown.
A protocol which cannot be extended is not a protocol that can grow new features.

I know what you mean. It's always a fine line between "too bloated" and "too crusted".
That said, I guess you could always increase the protocol version for major changes instead of stuffing them in amigous "option" fields in v1 - that's what the version is for, isn't it? 
But you guys surely know best.
They will only take up an extra 32 bits if not used.

I know it would be :hankey: 
Obviously string formatted integer would be a bit stupid as you can do string[0]->rune->int, but hey, at least it would be possible, versus having to wait for 2.0 to add something to the protocol.

But I think adding both `Flags uint32` and `[]Options` fields where they may be required is sensible. Plus the other changes (error codes, hashes). Of course, flags can always be sent as empty options as well (i.e. just the presence of "OptionSwizzledHashes" means something useful).

I started adding in the [v0.11-proto branch](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/v0.11-proto/internal/protocol/message.go). It doesn't build (nothing regenerated etc) but as a scratchpad for the work.

Could a (more) variable block size also be part of the final protocol, please? As far as I understand, blocks are all 128 kiB in size, except for the last one (which might be the only one too). https://discourse.syncthing.net/t/better-delta-sync-algorithm-like-rsync/984/14 seems like a reasonable implementation to determine splits in files by file content, not a fixed length. https://github.com/bup/bup for example uses such an algorithm to handle inserts in the middle of files better, check out bup-split.

You could still insist on having 128 kiB as maximum block size (though you seem to prefer this to be the "average" or "typical" size), then a splitting algorithm would simply split at the boundaries it finds or at 128 kiB, if no boundary was found since the last split. This might be necessary to prevent attacks on the splitting algo anyways.

Your current version of splitting files into blocks only works well with append-heavy file changes, bup-split works also with inserts and prepends and you need to hash the file anyways.

It would be nice to at least have the option to add such a feature to the client later on by making the file size requirements of blocks a bit more relaxed.
@MarkusTeufelberger At this point no, unless someone contributes that.
What else would we need for encryption? Extentions to blocks?
I don't know... But I'm pretty sure it should be a new major version anyway so I wouldn't worry about it too much. :)
